title: Can we have replays NOT be restricted by patch?
body: I understand there being a threshold for how many games back you can look at like 20 game limit or something. However I think it's kind of stupid that as soon as a patch hits I can't look at a game even if it only happened 2 days ago and I've played like 5 games total in that span of time (this is an example. I don't remember exactly the number but they were rather small.)

replies.body:
This.

A replay isn't technically a replay in the sense that the match itself was recorded. What actually happens is that the events from the game are recorded and the replay is actually a repetition from what happened in the game.

Think of it as a movie. Instead of directly recording the movie, you write what happened in the movie then you and some actors repeat the same exact things that happened in the movie as you wrote. I think that is what happens when a game is recorded.

And that's why they need to restrict replays by patch. Because some things change in the code of the game. For example, they can't allow you to watch a replay with old Yorick because the game can't use the code from old Yorick to repeat the events from the game that happened when old Yorick was in the game.

That'd a sound reason, if I wasn't using LoLReplay for years.
For some reason their replays worked perfectly after a year and after champion reworks.

Like when Rengar's E-Bola was changed from a point'n'click to a skillshot, it worked perfectly after I watched it a year later.

Of course in case of Yorick who completely lost all of his abilities that maybe wouldn't work, but why when I had a great Diana game in Twisted Treeline at 11PM and the patch with exactly zero changes to any champions in that match hit at 12PM the replay is garbage?

It should be painfully easy to add a check of "Was any champion in this match significantly reworked this patch?" to replay eligibility.

I'll take a stab at this even tho I'm in no way qualified to answer. 

So with how we do replays now: No, this is not possible

This is a problem with how replays are done as a whole.  To keep small file sizes and such, replays aren't recording the game, but the inputs from each player. When you play a replay back, you're really just watching your PC  emulate/play a game of League of Legends. When a new patch hits, your replay fucks up because of how the game changes patch to patch. Your PC gets confused when it is playing the same inputs and getting different results from the previous patch. (This kills the replay. ) 

For example, last patch, your Ez Q does 40 damage and the enemy barely lives. Replay plays this and this makes sense.

But this patch, when you play the replay back, your Ez Q does 50 damage and kills the enemy. Suddenly nothing makes sense anymore.

There are some janky ways to get around this. If interest is here, I can post a guide of how to play replays on an older patch ^^"

>I can post a guide of how to play replays on an older patch

Yes please

OK! I think this should work if you follow these steps

So first, you need to copy the version of League of Legends that you want to play the replay on (Ex. Patch 7.13). Name it, shove it on your HD, and never open it again. 

 THEN

1. Locate the replay file 
2. Select the replay from previous step and copy 
3. Navigate to the version of League where the replay was captured (e.g. C:\Riot Games\League of Legends\RADS\solutions\lol_game_client_sln\releases\0.0.1.134\deploy)
4. Find the LoL application in that folder and create a shortcut
5. Right-click the shortcut, select properties, then paste the copied replay file to the end of the target name (e.g. C:\Riot Games\League of Legends\RADS\solutions\lol_game_client_sln\releases\0.0.1.138\deploy\League of Legends.exe" "C:\Users\Rainslight\Downloads\NA1-2247576397.rofl")
6. Apply and OK
7. Double click the LoL shortcut to launch the replay!

Extra: If this is not working. Try adding "-UseRads" in between the target name and the replay name ^^

You're exactly correct. I'm a programmer. When I was about 7 years old, I wrote a kind of platform shooter something, inspired by games like Mario. It didn't have fancy graphics. I used simple ASCII characters to construct levels, enemies and players. Anyways, it had replay functionality and this is EXACTLY how I implemented it. 

The first thing I did was record the random seed used for the particular session that I was recording. This ensures that the same sequence of random numbers are generated. The random numbers are the basis for random events that take place in game, for example, when enemies choose to attack or the actions they choose to execute such as whether to jump, shoot or whatever. Using the same random seed ensures that every thing that happens randomly in the game will happen the EXACT same way.

The second thing I did was to record each time the player sent input to the game. This was followed by a duration code. The duration code was basically a number that says how much time has passed before the next input was sent. 

The recording of the random seed, duration and the sequence of inputs allowed me to reproduce the entire sequence of events that took place EXACTLY as they happened at the time of the recording. However, these recordings are only valid if certain parameters in the game engine remained unchanged. For example, if I changed how much damage a certain enemy does and try to play back a replay from before that change, the replay would desync at the first point where change in damage becomes relevant. If I my character does 20 damage and at some point I was shooting an enemy with 40 HP and I killed him. That would have taken 2 shots. But lets say I buffed the damage my character does to 40, then in the replay, the enemy would die in 1 shot instead of 2 and that extra shot might hit another enemy and kill him earlier than he was killed in the original playthrough. This would create a domino effect where the replay starts looking like the player is taking a bunch of random nonsensical actions like walking into walls or enemies, ignoring enemies etc.

Replays don't work after patches because they aren't traditional video files. Instead, they log the code of every action that happens in the game, and play it back. This way, it takes up a TON less space. Other games like Sm4sh and Brawhalla work the same. The problem with playing an old replay in a new patch is, if the code says "Veigar hits his W on Ashe and Lux", but in this new patch Veigar W now does 700% AP, and Rabadons, which Veigar rushed, now has 225 AP, the replay isn't going to be the same. 

I also assume that if something changes too much, like Lux being coded to Ult and kill 3 people, but now being dead, the client would crash, or start doing weird shit.

I remember how a year after Rengar's rework I watched an old replay from LoLReplay back from when Rengar had his bola point'n'click and guess what...

It worked exactly like it worked back then and LoLReplay replays are fundamentally identical to those we have right now.

Replays contain all actions and results, possibly skipping all server-side calculations, so whether Veigar's W has 1.0 AP ratio or does physical damage with 7.0 AS ratio is meaningless.

If I'm not mistaken, LoL Replay actually had you download that patch's files (Excluding things like skins and splashes to cut down on space, but it was still a weird and bulky way to backpatch replays)

In all likelihood, the replay system records everyone's inputs, and reruns the game with those inputs.  Given this, any changes to the game mechanics mean that the replays stop working.  This would also explain why you need the highlight tool to get actual videos of the game.  In all honesty, this type of thing is actually pretty common in a lot of games (Super Smash Brothers does this for replays too), because it takes way less space to store the stream of inputs than it does to store a video of the whole thing.

> **The game bugsplats when I start a replay, what do I do?**
> 
> If the replay is not from the current patch, you can try hitting the "Repair replay client" button from the "Replay settings" page. 

I *believe* they distributed old versions of the game through their replay client, cutting out everything that wasn't strictly necessary for a replay (such as splash arts, store assets, etc). You still ended up downloading multiple copies of the game. It works, but it's a bulky, sloppy solution.
